poem:
Sibling Savagery

In the digital glare,  
children wage their wars  
on padded battlegrounds,  
small fists echoing  
ancient feuds.  
The sister's blows  
fall like history's pages,  
turning, unsoftened  
by memory's embrace.  
Curious eyes  
consume their clash:  
innocence contorted  
in viral savagery,  
a question etched  
in the virtual air.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I thought my sister and I had the worst fights in history. Then I asked the internet | Lucinda Price How normal is sibling-on-sibling savagery? It’s a question I asked myself last week while watching two small children fight, Mike Tyson-style, on Instagram Reels. The kids, maybe four and two, wore boxing gloves and squared off on a grippy, padded floor. The older sister was thumping her brother like her life depended on it. His". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
